CHAPTER V.

CLERVAL then put the following letter into my hands.

To V. FRANKENSTEIN.

“MY DEAR COUSIN,

rdgGrp.n: ['chapter vi. <p-start/> c<hi>lerval</hi> then put the following letter into my hands. it was from my own elizabeth:—<p-end/> <p-start/>"my dearest cousin,<p-end/>']
rdgGrp.rdg:
CHAPTER VI.

CLERVAL then put the following letter into my hands. It was from my own Elizabeth:—

“My dearest Cousin,
“I cannot describe to you the uneasiness we have all felt concerning your health. We cannot help imagining that your friend Clerval conceals the extent of your
“I cannot describe to you the uneasiness we have all felt concerning your health. We cannot help imagining that your friend Clerval conceals the extent of your

We cannot help imagining that <lb n="c56-0058__main__3"/>your friend Clerval conceals the <w ana="start"/>ex<lb n="c56-0058__main__4"/>tent<w ana="end"/> of your

rdgGrp.n: ['"you have been ill, very ill, and even the constant letters of dear kind henry are not sufficient to reassure me on your account. you are forbidden to write—to hold a pen; yet one word from you, dear victor, is necessary to calm our apprehensions. for a long time i have thought that each post would bring this line, and my persuasions have', 'restrained']
rdgGrp.rdg: “You have been ill, very ill, and even the constant letters of dear kind Henry are not sufficient to reassure me on your account. You are forbidden to write—to hold a pen; yet one word from you, dear Victor, is necessary to calm our apprehensions. For a long time I have thought that each post would bring this line, and my persuasions have restrained

rdgGrp.n: ['i have prevented his encountering the inconveniences and perhaps dangers of so long a journey; yet how often have i regretted not being able to perform it myself! i figure to myself that the task of attending on your sick bed has devolved on some mercenary old nurse, who could never guess your wishes, nor minister to them with the care and affection of your poor cousin. yet that is over now:']
rdgGrp.rdg: I have prevented his encountering the inconveniences and perhaps dangers of so long a journey; yet how often have I regretted not being able to perform it myself! I figure to myself that the task of attending on your sick bed has devolved on some mercenary old nurse, who could never guess your wishes, nor minister to them with the care and affection of your poor cousin. Yet that is over now:

rdgGrp.n: ['handwriting.', '<p-end/>', '<p-start/>', '"get well—and return to us. you will find a happy, cheerful home, and friends who love you dearly.']
rdgGrp.rdg:
handwriting.

“Get well—and return to us. You will find a happy, cheerful home, and friends who love you dearly.

<mod sID="c56-0058__main__d5e12009"/> <del rend="strikethrough" xml:id="c56-0058__main__d5e12011">uneasy</del> <sga-add place="sublinear" sID="c56-0058__main__d5e12014"/> <metamark function="insert">^</metamark> <sga-add eID="c56-0058__main__d5e12014"/><sga-add place="superlinear" sID="c56-0058__main__d5e12020"/>miserable on this
and we shall be the happiest creatures in the world.
and we shall be the happiest creatures in the world.
and we shall be the happiest creatures in the world.
and we shall <lb n="c56-0058__main__23"/>be the happiest creatures in the <lb n="c56-0058__main__24"/>world.–

rdgGrp.n: ['and he asks but to see you,—but to be assured that you are well; and not a care will ever cloud his benevolent countenance.', 'how', 'pleased']
rdgGrp.rdg: and he asks but to see you,—but to be assured that you are well; and not a care will ever cloud his benevolent countenance. How pleased
that he appears ten years younger since last winter. Ernest also is so much improved,

rdgGrp.n: ['is', 'now', 'sixteen,', 'and', 'full of activity and spirit.', 'he is desirous to be a true swiss, and to enter into foreign service; but we cannot part with him, at least until his elder brother return to us. my uncle is not pleased with the idea of a military career in a distant country; but ernest never had your powers of application. he looks upon study as an odious fetter;—his time is spent']
rdgGrp.rdg: is now sixteen, and full of activity and spirit. He is desirous to be a true Swiss, and to enter into foreign service;<pb xml:id="F1831_v_066" n="50"/> but we cannot part with him, at least until his elder brother return to us. My uncle is not pleased with the idea of a military career in a distant country; but Ernest never had your powers of application. He looks upon study as an odious fetter;—his time is spent

rdgGrp.n: ['i fear that he will become an idler, unless we yield the point, and permit him to enter on the profession which he has selected.<p-end/> <p-start/>"little alteration, except the growth of our dear children, has taken place since you left us. the blue lake, and snow-clad mountains, they never change;—and i think our placid home, and our contented hearts are regulated by the same immutable laws. my trifling occupations take up my time and amuse me, and i am rewarded for any exertions by seeing none but happy, kind faces around me. since you left us, but one change has taken place in our little household.', 'do you remember on what occasion justine moritz entered our family?']
rdgGrp.rdg:
I fear that he will become an idler, unless we yield the point, and permit him to enter on the profession which he has selected.

“Little alteration, except the growth of our dear children, has taken place since you left us. The blue lake, and snow-clad mountains, they never change;—and I think our placid home, and our contented hearts are regulated by the same immutable laws. My trifling occupations take up my time and amuse me, and I am rewarded for any exertions by seeing none but happy, kind faces around me. Since you left us, but one change has taken place in our little household. Do you remember on what occasion Justine Moritz entered our family?

but my anxiety returns upon me as I conclude. Write, dearest Victor,—one line—one word will be a blessing to us. Ten thousand thanks to Henry for his kindness, his affection, and his many letters: we are sincerely grateful. Adieu! my cousin; take care of yourself; and, I entreat you, write!
